intro: Papaver nudicaule subsp. commune, commonly known as the common poppy, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its striking, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink and red, often with a dark center. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in meadows and grasslands. The flowers bloom from late spring to early summer, producing a showy display that attracts pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
